Massachusetts General Laws (M.G.L.) c. 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws (M.G.L.) c. 208, § 28, which permits the Probate and Family Court to modify custody orders based on a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the minor child.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Massachusetts Child Custody statute, M.G.L. c. 208, § 31, and applicable case law require the Court to focus on the child’s best interests above the preferences or convenience of either parent.

*R.H. v. B.F.*, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (2.proposition: The Defendant’s relocation to New Hampshire constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (2.case_name: Massachusetts Highway Department v. Massachusetts Organization of State Engineers & Scientists
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not R.H. v. B.F. at all; it is a labor/arbitration case involving the Massachusetts Highway Department, MOSES, and grievances over out-of-title work and arbitration deadlines. It does not involve family law, relocation, material and substantial change in circumstances, or any custody/relocation analysis. Accordingly, this case cannot support the proposition that a defendant’s relocation to New Hampshire constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Background. Several provisions of the collective bargaining agreement lie at the heart of the present controversy… Under Section 16.2, MOSES members who performed ‘out-of-title’ work… were entitled to compensation at the higher level.… The central issues in this case involve application of those provisions.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts in Massachusetts consistently prioritize the best interests of the child, including ensuring continuity, stability, and access to school, routine, and relationships.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the removal question under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as turning on the “best interests” of the children and repeatedly applies that standard. In doing so, the court emphasizes factors such as the child’s current school supports, comparative school quality, the harms of “uprooting” and disruption, and preserving the father’s parenting time—all elements of continuity, stability, schooling, and relationships. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts prioritize the child’s best interests in this holistic way.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

*T.M. v. D.R.*, 93 Mass. App. Ct. 775 (2.proposition: Extended travel for a minor child is disruptive to her education and well-being.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The existing orders were predicated on the geography and proximity of the parents, which has now changed in a way that negatively impacts the child.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The case discusses initial custody and removal out of the jurisdiction, not a modification of existing orders based on a change in geography or proximity after entry of those orders. The opinion does recognize that removal will adversely affect the father’s ability to visit regularly, but it is not framed as a change from prior geographically based arrangements; instead, the move and its visitation consequences are evaluated in the first instance under the ‘real advantage’ and best-interests standards. Thus it does not support a proposition about existing orders being predicated on prior proximity that has now changed.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s task was to assess the effect of such a move on the children in circumstances in which the move would clearly benefit the wife but would adversely affect the father’s right to visit his children regularly. … The fact that visitation by the noncustodial parent will be changed to his or her disadvantage cannot be controlling.”

*El Chaar v. Clark*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: *El Chaar v. Clark*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (2015)
*El Chaar v. Clark*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: A midweek overnight for a school-aged child who attends school in one state while being required to stay overnight in another unduly burdens the child based on logistical considerations and travel time.

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: This Court has the discretion to amend parenting schedules in light of changes in work, location, or other life circumstances.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the Yannas ‘real advantage’ framework, not a general modification of parenting schedules due to changes in work, location, or other life circumstances. While it discusses modification standards under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and recognizes remarriage as a material and substantial change, the opinion does not frame this as broad ‘discretion to amend parenting schedules’; it focuses narrowly on relocation/removal and custody modification. Thus it is not accurate authority for the broader proposition stated.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “It appears that the judge may also have been influenced in his view of the mother’s remarriage and accompanying desire to move by his opinion that no changed circumstances were present, and thus no ground existed for modifying the divorce judgment. … Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification. … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

*G.A.G. v. J.M.E.A.*, 2013 Mass. App. Un.raw_text: *G.A.G. v. J.M.E.A.*, 2013 Mass. App. Unpub. LEXIS 613
*G.A.G. v. J.M.E.A.*, 2013 Mass. App. Un.proposition: The Plaintiff’s proposed schedule would allow the Defendant to maintain meaningful parenting time with the minor child while protecting the minor child’s physical, emotional, and developmental well-being.

*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.proposition: The Massachusetts Child Custody statute, M.G.L. c. 208, § 31, and applicable case law require the Court to focus on the child’s best interests above the preferences or convenience of either parent.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that in custody determinations the governing principle is the best interests of the child, citing earlier Massachusetts authority. While the case’s main holding is about the right to cross-examine a guardian ad litem, its discussion frames the investigator’s role as assisting the judge in determining the child’s best interests, not parental preferences or convenience. It does not analyze M.G.L. c. 208, § 31 specifically, but it is consistent with and supportive of the general best-interests standard reflected in that statute and related case law.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.relevant_excerpt: “There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). … In a custody proceeding, a judge makes a determination as to what is in the best interests of the child on the basis of facts presented at trial as well as facts gathered by the court-appointed investigators.”
